quiz.title: Unit 8: Factor Markets (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Capital Markets, Interest Rates, Investment Decisions
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Capital, Interest, Present Value, Investment Demand, Loanable Funds, Tariffs, Derived Demand, Human Capital Subsidies, Optimal Input Allocation, MP vs. MRP

questions.question: In economics, 'capital' refers to
options: money used to start a business
human skills and education
manufactured resources used to produce goods and services
stocks and bonds
questions.explanation: Capital in factor market context means physical capital: tools, machinery, buildings, and other produced means of production.

questions.question: The interest rate is the price paid for
options: the use of land
the use of labor
the use of money
consumer goods
questions.explanation: Interest is the payment for borrowing money (or the return for lending it), representing the price of credit in capital markets.

questions.question: The present value of a future sum of money is
options: higher when the interest rate is higher
lower when the interest rate is higher
unaffected by the interest rate
the same as its future value
questions.explanation: Present value = Future Value / (1 + r)ⁿ. A higher interest rate (r) discounts future money more heavily, lowering present value.

questions.question: A firm will invest in a capital project if
options: the present value of expected returns exceeds the cost
the future value is positive
the interest rate is zero
it has enough cash on hand
questions.explanation: Investment decisions compare the present value of expected future profits (marginal revenue product of capital) to the initial cost of the investment.

questions.question: The loanable funds market determines
options: the wage rate
the price of land
the real interest rate
the level of government spending
questions.explanation: The loanable funds model shows how the supply of savings and demand for borrowing interact to set the equilibrium real interest rate.

questions.question: An increase in the demand for loanable funds will lead to
options: a lower interest rate and more investment
a higher interest rate and less investment
a higher interest rate and more investment
no change in interest rates
questions.explanation: Increased demand for borrowing shifts the demand curve for loanable funds right, raising the interest rate and increasing the quantity of funds loaned (investment).

questions.question: The nominal interest rate equals
options: real interest rate + inflation rate
real interest rate − inflation rate
inflation rate only
real interest rate only
questions.explanation: Nominal interest rate ≈ real interest rate + expected inflation rate (Fisher equation).

questions.question: If the expected rate of return on an investment is 8% and the interest rate is 5%, the firm should
options: invest, because return > cost of borrowing
not invest, because return < cost of borrowing
invest only if the interest rate rises
wait for inflation to increase
questions.explanation: If the expected return (8%) exceeds the interest rate (cost of borrowing, 5%), the investment is profitable.

questions.question: Which of the following would increase the supply of loanable funds?
options: Higher government borrowing
Increased household saving
A decrease in investment demand
Higher inflation expectations
questions.explanation: More saving increases the supply of loanable funds, shifting the supply curve right.

questions.question: Crowding out occurs when
options: private investment decreases due to increased government borrowing
private saving increases due to tax cuts
interest rates fall because of more saving
firms invest more because of higher returns
questions.explanation: Crowding out: higher government borrowing increases demand for loanable funds, raising interest rates and reducing private investment.

questions.question: If a country imposes tariffs on imported goods, how would domestic employment and domestic product prices likely change?
options: Domestic employment decreases, Domestic product prices increase
Domestic employment increases, Domestic product prices increase
Domestic employment increases, Domestic product prices decrease
Domestic employment decreases, Domestic product prices decrease
questions.explanation: Tariffs raise the price of imports, making domestic goods relatively cheaper and increasing demand for them. This higher demand for domestic products can increase output and employment in domestic industries, but domestic product prices may also rise due to reduced foreign competition and higher input costs.

questions.question: Which of the following factors would most likely shift the derived demand for labor to the right?
options: Stricter government regulations.
A decrease in technological efficiency.
An increase in consumer demand for the firm’s product.
Higher wages in the industry.
questions.explanation: Derived demand for labor comes from demand for the final product. An increase in consumer demand for the product raises the marginal revenue product (MRP) of labor, shifting labor demand right.

questions.question: In what way can a subsidy provided by the government directly to workers for skill development affect the factor market?
options: It can create a surplus of unskilled labor as workers leave those positions for training opportunities.
It can reduce overall employment as firms may rely more on technology than subsidized skilled workers.
It can lead to an increase in human capital and potentially shift the supply curve for skilled labor to the right.
It can result in higher wages without changing employment levels or productivity rates.
questions.explanation: A subsidy for skill development (e.g., training, education) increases workers’ human capital, making them more productive and increasing the supply of skilled labor, shifting the supply curve right.

questions.question: When a profit-maximizing firm in a perfectly competitive labor market has achieved optimal input allocation, which of the following must be true?
options: MPL/MPK = w/r
MPL/w = MPK/r
MPL - w = MPK - r
MPL × w = MPK × r
questions.explanation: The least‑cost rule for optimal input allocation states that MP per dollar spent on each input must be equal: MPL / w = MPK / r.

questions.question: What is the relationship between marginal product and marginal revenue product?
options: Marginal product and marginal revenue product are always equal
Marginal product and marginal revenue product are unrelated
When marginal product increases, so does marginal revenue product
When marginal decreases, so does marginal revenue product
questions.explanation: MRP = MPL × MR (or MPL × P under perfect competition). Thus, if MPL increases (and MR or P remains constant), MRP also increases. Similarly, a decrease in MPL typically decreases MRP.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of capital concepts, interest rates, present value, investment decisions, loanable funds, tariffs, derived demand, human capital subsidies, optimal input rule, and MP‑MRP relationship.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review present value calculations, loanable funds shifts, nominal vs. real rates, crowding out, derived demand shifts, and least‑cost rule.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice applying present value, understanding loanable funds model, distinguishing nominal/real rates, and applying derived demand and input allocation rules.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on capital definition, present value formula, investment rule (return > interest rate), loanable funds market, crowding out, derived demand definition, MP/w = MP/r, and MRP = MPL × MR.
